• Although parents often play a supportive role in students' lives, once a student is considered an [TERM eligible student]a student who has reached 18 years of age OR is attending a postsecondary institution[/TERM], rights under FERPA transfer to the student.

  • Regardless of who pays tuition costs, parents DO NOT have rights to students' education records in the college setting.

Although the law states that rights under FERPA are transferred from parents to eligible students, there are exceptions which allow an institution to share educational records with parents. FERPA allows institutions the option to provide parents with information within the student's education record in the following cases:

  • parents of dependent children for income tax purposes

    • Age does not matter. If the student is legally considered a dependent for income tax purposes, the university or learning institution, MAY (according to FERPA) allow these parents access to part or all of the dependent student's education record.

    • Providing parents of dependent students access to students' education records is left to the discretion of the school. Therefore, FERPA does not make it a mandatory action. The institution can decide what information, if any, it discloses in this case.

    • health and safety emergencies if the information is necessary to protect the health and safety of the student or others

      • notification of drug and alcohol violations as long as the student:

        • was found guilty AND

        • is under 21
